Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: BCSP: Robustness and Adaptation in Morphogenetic Collective Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The objective of this project is to understand the roles of general morphogenetic principles such as heterogeneity of components, differentiation/re-differentiation of components, and local information exchange among components in the self-organization of biological collectives, and to utilize them to improve the performance of collective artificial systems. The research is conducted in the following four steps: (1) Study the effects of morphogenetic principles on self-organizing patterns of heterogeneous collectives using mathematical/computational models. (2) Apply the results of theoretical investigation to construct models of actual self-organizing patterns found in real-world heterogeneous biological collectives. (3) Introduce the morphogenetic principles to existing collective artificial systems and develop mechanisms for programming their structures and behaviors. (4) Measure the overall performance of the proposed morphogenetic collective systems in decentralized optimization and exploration tasks. This research contributes to biology and ecology by providing new theoretical insight into how heterogeneous collectives may self-organize without centralized control, and also to computational science and engineering by bringing an unexplored combination of morphogenetic principles into bio-inspired computational systems. It is expected to produce societal impacts by providing a novel framework for the design of growing, self-organizing, self-repairing, and evolving artifacts. This project involves the following educational activities: (1) Interdisciplinary graduate certificate program in complex systems science. (2) New course on computational approaches to the origin and evolution of life. (3) Regional high school research program. (4) Public exhibition of morphogenetic collective systems at New York Hall of Science. Efforts will be made to attract female and ethnic minority students who are currently underrepresented in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Virtually all biological systems are collective systems, in the sense that they are made of a large number of smaller entities. Examples include cells forming an individual organism, individual organisms forming a flock or a herd, and so on. Those smaller entities interact with each other to show a wide variety of self-organizing behaviors as a whole. Such self-organization of biological complex systems has been subject to many scientific inquiries. However, earlier studies were mostly focused on homogeneous collectives, often failing in capturing more complex phenomena seen in real-world biological collectives, such as multi-cellular organisms’ morphogenesis and physiology, termite colony building and maintenance, and growth and self-organization of human social systems. What are commonly present within those real-world complex biological collectives are heterogeneity of components, dynamic state changes of components, and local information exchange among components that influence their state changes. These morphogenetic principles were missing in earlier models of biological collective behaviors, and they have not been fully utilized in engineering applications either.  

This NSF-funded project aimed to understand the roles of those morphogenetic principles in the self-organization of biological collectives, and to utilize them to improve the performance of collective artificial systems. The research was conducted on the following four subtasks: (1) Study the effects of morphogenetic principles on self-organizing patterns of heterogeneous collectives using mathematical/computational models. (2) Apply the results of theoretical investigation to construct models of actual self-organizing patterns found in real-world heterogeneous biological collectives. (3) Introduce the morphogenetic principles to existing collective artificial systems and develop mechanisms for programming their structures and behaviors. (4) Measure the overall performance of the proposed morphogenetic collective systems in decentralized optimization and exploration tasks.

The results of this project produced several novel discoveries and developments: (1) Each of the morphogenetic principles has unique, distinct effects on the resulting morphogenetic processes. Heterogeneity of components has quite significant effects on various properties of the collective systems, while the ability for individuals to dynamically switch their states helps make more diverse morphologies and behaviors in those collective systems. (2) This project developed new algorithm and software that can track moving individuals in an ordinary video recording and then create a dynamical model of their collective behavior. (3) The dynamical “criticality” of control mechanisms inside each individual component helps make the resulting morphology more non-trivial, and improve their evolutionary robustness and adaptability as well. (4) Including the morphogenetic principles in computational search/optimization algorithms can improve their performance significantly.

The outcomes of this project have been disseminated via various publications and presentations. Four workshops were organized on this topic to disseminate the results and promote the growth of the related research field. This project also involved the following educational activities: (1) Integration of project outcomes into courses offered through the interdisciplinary graduate certificate program in complex systems science at Binghamton University. (2) Regional high school research program. (3) Public exhibition of morphogenetic collective systems through online videos and simulation software.
